awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Development and Validation of Analytic Spatial-Temporal Models to Help Study and Mitigate the National Opioid-Heroin Co-Epidemic
awd_abstract_narration:
The US is In the midst of a serious epidemic of opioid drug misuse and abuse. According to the Surgeon General's 2016 report, "Facing Addiction in America", in 2014, 28,647 people died from drug overdoses involving some type of opioid, including prescription pain relievers, heroin, and fentanyl.  The report states that the "accumulated costs to the individual, the family, and the community are staggering and arise as a consequence of many direct and indirect effects, including compromised physical and mental health, increased spread of infectious disease, loss of productivity, reduced quality of life, increased crime and violence, increased motor vehicle crashes, abuse and neglect of children, and health care costs."  The report also recognizes the potential for advances in clinical, operational, and informational technologies, coupled with health care and criminal justice reform efforts, to drive improvements in prevention and treatment services.  This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will address operational methods to understand and mitigate multiple interrelated opioid addiction epidemics.  The methods will be developed and evaluated with ongoing feedback from an advisory group of policy makers, including state health departments serving multiple urban and rural populations.  The potential impact of these new methods includes improved prevention strategies and support for effective allocation of resources between treatment and interdiction.  The project will also educate several graduate and undergraduate engineering students who will be in a position to help provide solutions to current public sector issues that threaten the nation's health and security.

This award will support research to formulate high fidelity spatiotemporal analytical models of the interdependent national opioid and heroin disease epidemics.  The model(s) developed will combine approaches based on differential equations, cellular automata, stochastic processes and will incorporate different geographic and social network topologies, account for regional and population heterogeneity, and capture behavioral characteristics that influence dynamics of disease spread.  An important aspect of these models is the explicit consideration of the inter-relationships between multiple disease modalities, including such factors as substance availability, addiction progression, drug switching and substitutability, variable drug potency, and market (price/supply/demand) forces.  The models will be developed and validated using data obtained from local and regional public health agencies.  Models will be informed by qualitative ethnographic techniques that describe the dynamics of person-to-person spread and region-to-region spread.  These models will serve as platforms for the assessment of current and future intervention strategies, and are expected to help inform policy makers that oversee resource allocation in state public health departments, treatment centers, social service agencies, and law enforcement agencies.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed, validated, and applied a set of multi-drug co-epidemic models of the ongoing U.S. opioid and heroin crisis, to-date resulting in estimates exceeding 13 million hospitalizations, $1 trillion in costs, and 500,000 deaths since 1999. We developed a set of a mathematical models of increasing complexity, based on population (differential equation) and individual (agent-based) susceptible-exposed-infected-recovered frameworks, of the spread of pharmaceutical opioid misuse and illicit opioid use (non-prescription opioids, heroin, fentanyl), including a novel parameterization approach using non-greedy search algorithms to optimize model accuracy. Results can be used to develop insights into substance abuse behavior, predict and detect changes in epidemic trajectories, and evaluate potential interventions. We applied all developed models to a wide range of national, county, state, and town data that historically experienced different epidemic patterns, including some known to be opioid epidemic hotspots, with the best cases producing strong fits. A series of experiments were conducted to investigate model complexity-accuracy tradeoffs and to estimate impacts of various interventions proposed in the literature, individually and in combinations.

   The best final models accurately reproduced historical prescriptions, overdoses, deaths, and admissions to addiction treatment across various locations and scales (state, county, town) with high accuracy (2-4% error), exceeding results reported in past literature, and helped identify key insights. Prescribing of opioids for chronic pain and prescription misuse-to-heroin pathways had high impacts on later overdoses and epidemic severity, consistent with Centers for Disease Control and Prevention empirical research and contrary to common interventions that instead target over-prescribing for acute pain. Acute and chronic prescription rates that maximized model fit also were consistent with those seen in practice, while model-identified epidemic local change points corresponded to the timing of regional launches of prescription monitoring programs or the emergence of fentanyl. In terms of generalizability, the developed models also were successfully adapted to study other substance abuse epidemics (adolescent vaping of nicotine, marijuana, and/or tetrahydrocannabinol (THC); alcohol abuse and mental health surges during the COVID-19 pandemic), producing similar accuracy and results.

   Significant contributions of this research include development of new multi-scale multi-drug models of inter-related substance abuse co-epidemics, application of these models to a range of settings to test and improve accuracy, analysis of different types of potential interventions to reduce such epidemics, and investigation of new approaches to model parameterization and start-up, the latter being notable gaps in the research literature. Broader impacts of this project include the development of general methodologic approaches to accurately modeling, parameterizing, and applying such models to effectively study other multi-substance and/or multi-epidemic problems.
